items.title: Avoid using __stdc_version__ macro because it is implementation dependent
items.body:
From the GNU compiler pages:

```
__STDC_VERSION__
This macro expands to the C Standard’s version number, a long integer constant of the form yyyymmL where yyyy and mm are the year and month of the Standard version. This signifies which version of the C Standard the compiler conforms to. Like __STDC__, this is not necessarily accurate for the entire implementation, unless GNU CPP is being used with GCC.

The value 199409L signifies the 1989 C standard as amended in 1994, which is the current default; the value 199901L signifies the 1999 revision of the C standard; the value 201112L signifies the 2011 revision of the C standard; the value 201710L signifies the 2017 revision of the C standard (which is otherwise identical to the 2011 version apart from correction of defects). An unspecified value larger than 201710L is used for the experimental -std=c2x and -std=gnu2x modes.

This macro is not defined if the -traditional-cpp option is used, nor when compiling C++ or Objective-C.
```

I think you can instead use the __cplusplus macro...

items.title: Revert #3086
items.body:
As discussed in #3086 and sass/dart-sass#996, this broke with the specified behavior of the language and should not have been made without going through the [formal process for changes to the Sass language](https://github.com/sass/sass/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

This is a tracking bug for TODOs in sass-spec that can be removed once #3086 is reverted.

items.title: Issue with certain std::unorder_map implementations
items.body:
I found this via perl-libsass smokers, specially on older FreeBSD systems.
E.g. http://www.cpantesters.org/cpan/report/279ec77a-8cde-11ea-9066-e374b0ba08e8

```
#   Failed test 'CSS: t/sass-spec/spec/libsass-closed-issues/issue_1667/input.scss'
#   at t/99_sass_specs.t line 559.
# +---+------------------------+---+------------------------+
# | Ln|Got                     | Ln|Expected                |
# +---+------------------------+---+------------------------+
# |  1|'foo {                  |  1|'foo {                  |
# *  2|  a: 1px}               *  2|  a: 1;                 *
# |   |                        *  3|  b: 1px}               *
# |  3|h1 {                    |  4|h1 {                    |
# |  4|  font-size: 2.221rem}  |  5|  font-size: 2.221rem}  |
# |  5|h1 small {              |  6|h1 small {              |
# |  6|  font-size: 1.586rem;  |  7|  font-size: 1.586rem;  |
# |  7|  color: red}           |  8|  color: red}           |
# |  8|'                       |  9|'                       |
# +---+------------------------+---+------------------------+
```

It looks like the underlying std::unordered_map punishes us for not
having the hash in sync with the equality check. IMO it has all the
rights to do so, so we should probably try to avoid this. Although
I think it will go away once we remove unitless number equality.

```
FreeBSD clang version 6.0.0 (tags/RELEASE_600/final 326565) (based on LLVM 6.0.0)
Target: i386-unknown-freebsd11.2
Thread model: posix
```

items.title: Getters for plugin paths missing in public API
items.body: In the [Context API Docs](https://github.com/sass/libsass/blob/master/docs/api-context.md), the getter functions `sass_option_get_plugin_path` and `sass_option_get_plugin_path_size` are described. However, these functions are not implemented in the actual API. This seems like an oversight to me. Either the docs should be updated to reflect the API, or (preferably) the API should be updated to reflect the docs.

items.title: Segmentation Fault destructuring with @each
Compile error:  "Cannot read property 'type' of undefined"
items.body:
Not sure if this is a Node Sass error or a Create React App webpack build error. 
When running CRA build script with Node Sass as a dependency, I was getting a vague error 

```BASH
Failed to compile.

Cannot read property 'type' of undefined
CompileError: Begins at CSS selector undefined
```

In local development, everything was working fine, no compile errors. 

After a fun debugging session, I found that I had a `translate3d` transform value that was missing a 0

The following causes compile error:
```CSS
transform: translate3d(0, 0);
```

The following fixed the compile error
```CSS 
transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
```



- NPM version (`npm -v`): 6.13.4
- Node version (`node -v`): v12.16.1
- Node Platform (`node -p process.platform`): win32
- Node architecture (`node -p process.arch`): x64
- node-sass version (`node -p "require('node-sass').info"`):  4.13.1
- npm node-sass versions (`npm ls node-sass`): 4.13.1

I am the process of upgrading the libsass version of node-sass if has any relevance in regards to this issue. 

The inputs and outputs I've listed here are from the 3.6.3 sass-spec repo (specifically `spec/core_functions/color/adjust_color/error/bounds.hrx`). The alpha argument isn't throwing any errors when it should be throwing errors. The arguments for red, blue, green, lightness, and saturation do throw errors when given a value that is out of the proper range. 

I am unsure how that is possible because those arguments involve calling the same function `get_arg_r` in the libsass library.

In addition, I discovered on the Javascript side that not only is there no error, but that the `css` attribute in the `result` object passed to the callback to `sass.render` is a Uint8Array instead of a string.

items.title: :root selector should always go at the beginning of a selector

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: Currently, it's possible for libsass's unification to nest the `:root` selector beneath another selector. For example, `selector-unify(":root .c", ".d .e")` current returns `:root .d .c.e, .d :root .c.e`, but the latter selector cannot possibly match any elements and so should be omitted.

Sandro

items.title: Variables are not replaced/computed in SVG variable definitions

items.body:

**Machine Setup**
```
Machine : Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
gcc version 5.4.0 20160609 (Ubuntu 5.4.0-6ubuntu1~16.04.11)
Commit : d911058
Command : sassc POC
```
**Compilation** : CC=afl-clang-fast CXX=afl-clang-fast++ AFL_USE_ASAN=1 make -C sassc -j4
**POC** : [POC-2.zip](https://github.com/sass/libsass/files/3826015/POC-2.zip)

items.title: Sometimes the `sass_context_get_error_src` method returns an invalid pointer
items.body: I am using the LibSass version 3.6.2. When compiling a large file (for example, modified `_theming.scss` file from the [Angular Material](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/material) package version 8.2.3), that contains a syntax error near the end of file, `sass_context_get_error_src` method may return an invalid pointer instead of the source code of this file.

items.title: Compiling hangs when selectors with ">" are present
@mixin argument not expanded in CSS custom property
Change "Sanctioned" to "Approved" in Readme.md for 3rd-Party Implementation List
items.body:
# Change `"Sanctioned"` to `"Approved"` in Readme.md for 3rd-Party Implementation List

Have you noticed how the word **sanction** can have different, practically opposite, meanings in different contexts? In some cases, it can mean something like a _penalty_, while in others, it can mean something like an _endorsement_. The meaning can also be shaped by whether the use is in noun-form, like "a sanction", or verb-form, like "to sanction" or "sanctioned activity" (past participle).

This [English StackExchange post](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/48837/how-did-sanction-come-to-have-two-opposite-meanings) discusses the differences quite well and points out how many usages today by journalists muddy the difference.

This is absolutely a subjective opinion, but to me, when I see

> Excerpt of "sanctioned" implementations:

in the [Readme.md](https://github.com/sass/libsass/blob/4da7c4bd13b8e9e5cd034f358dceda0bbba917d2/Readme.md) , I read, "Excerpt of *bad for some reason/unapproved* implementations".

The addition of the quotes surrounding "sanctioned" also gives me pause as to what the writer is signalling. Is this a quotation? **Is this unusual usage of the word**? Hmm.

But then, you can sort of piece it together and realize the writer is listing implementations that are somehow _approved_.

Again, subjective, but, regarding the [current Readme.md](https://github.com/sass/libsass/blob/4da7c4bd13b8e9e5cd034f358dceda0bbba917d2/Readme.md), I would like to see:

- [x] Change of the word "sanctioned" to "approved" to make it explicitly clear the purpose of the list, given the ambiguous meaning of that word.
- [x] Don't use quotations, regardless of the chosen word. 
- [x] Title-case this heading line altogether.

Please pardon me if this non-productive.

items.title: Hanging with 3.6.2 when generating breeze-gtk (worked with 3.6.1)
items.body:
## input.scss

split into multiple files: https://cgit.kde.org/breeze-gtk.git/tree/src

invocation of sassc via

CMakeLists.txt
```
...
add_custom_command(
    OUTPUT ${Breeze_TARGETS}
    DEPENDS ${SOURCES}
    COMMAND ./build_theme.sh -c Breeze -t "${PROJECT_BINARY_DIR}/Breeze" -r "${BREEZE_COLOR_INSTALL_ROOT}"
    COMMAND cp gtk-dark-3.0.css "${PROJECT_BINARY_DIR}/Breeze/gtk-3.0/gtk-dark.css"
    WORKING_DIRECTORY "${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/src"
)
...
```

build_theme.sh
```
...
# Usage: build_sass <source-directory> <target-directory> <include-directory>
build_sass() {
  if command -v sassc >/dev/null 2>&1; then
      sassc -I "$3" "$1" "$2"
  else
      sass -I "$3" --cache-location /tmp/sass-cache "$1" "$2"
  fi
}
...
```

## Actual results

Hangs indefinitely

version info:
```
$ sassc -v
sassc: na
libsass: na
sass2scss: 1.1.1
sass: 3.5

Have to check where the "na" comes from but it is 3.6.2 (sassc-3.6.1) built from a tarball (I guess the information from git might be missing there).

Passing just fine as with 3.6.1

version info:
```
sassc -v
sassc: na
libsass: na
sass2scss: 1.1.1
sass: 3.5

items.title: Incomplete warning since 3.6.2 when extending compound selectors
items.body:
Bug was ported from https://github.com/sass/libsass-python/issues/303

## input.scss

```scss
.form-control[disabled] {
    display: block;
}
.select2-container--disabled {
    @extend .form-control[disabled];
}
```

## Actual results

[libsass 3.6.2][1] via python wrapper libsass 0.19.3.
```
compound selectors may no longer be extended.
Consider `@extend ${compound.components.join(', ')}` instead.
See http://bit.ly/ExtendCompound for details.
```

## Expected result

No warning.

version info:
```cmd
$ pip list |grep sass                                                                           :(
libsass                            0.19.3      
```

Original bug Report below:

To trigger this, try to feed this to the sass compiler:

```
sass.compile(string='''
.form-control[disabled] {
    display: block;
}
.select2-container--disabled {
    @extend .form-control[disabled];
}
''')
```

This is tested with libsass 0.19.3. Feeding this to the sass compiler will emit this warning:

```
compound selectors may no longer be extended.
Consider `@extend ${compound.components.join(', ')}` instead.
See http://bit.ly/ExtendCompound for details.
```

I think there are several things wrong with this warning message.

a) the URL doesn't lead to where it should, it resolves to <https://sass-lang.com/documentation> instead of the correct <https://sass-lang.com/documentation/breaking-changes/extend-compound>

b) the 'Consider...' message is a bit confusing. I think it would be clearer to state 'Consider joining the css classes by commas to document instead.'

c) the message doesn't give any context of file and line number, making it very hard to actually fix anything.

d) as my example shows, this seems to be raised even if it doesn't apply, as there is no compound selector in my example.

items.title: Compressed style should not remove meaningful space between selectors
items.body:
## input.scss

```scss
.foo .bar {
  top: 0;
}
```

## Actual results (output style: compressed)

```css
.foo.bar{top:0}
```

The combinator space between `.foo` and `.bar` is incorrectly removed.

## Expected result (output style: compressed)

```css
.foo .bar{top:0}
```

There is a space between `.foo` and `.bar` as in the source (meaning that the rule is valid in case `.bar` is a descendant of `.foo`).
## Version info

```cmd
$ sassc -v
sassc: 3.6.1-5-g507f0
libsass: 3.6.1-36-geb54
sass2scss: 1.1.1
sass: 3.5
```

items.title: unary dash in @mixin uses same value every @include
@extend ignores @mixin
Feature Request for Multi-line Indented Properties
items.body:
## input.sass

```sass
body
  main
    display: grid
    grid-template-columns: repeat(6, 1fr)
    grid-template-rows: repeat(6, 1fr)
    grid-gap: 10px

    align-items: center
    justify-items: center

    grid-template-areas:
      - "top-left top-left top-center top-center top-right top-right"
      - "top-left top-left top-center top-center top-right top-right"
      - "middle-left middle-left middle-center middle-center middle-right middle-right"
      - "middle-left middle-left middle-center middle-center middle-right middle-right"
      - "bottom-left bottom-left bottom-center bottom-center bottom-right bottom-right"
      - "bottom-left bottom-left bottom-center bottom-center bottom-right bottom-right"
```

## Actual results

Get error about invalid CSS and/or unexpected token depending on who you ask. Naturally, as this is not a part of the spec (yet).

## Expected result

```css
body main {
    display: grid;
    grid-template-columns: repeat(6, 1fr);
    grid-template-rows: repeat(6, 1fr);
    grid-gap: 10px;
    align-items: center;
    justify-items: center;
    grid-template-areas: "top-left top-left top-center top-center top-right top-right" "top-left top-left top-center top-center top-right top-right" "middle-left middle-left middle-center middle-center middle-right middle-right" "middle-left middle-left middle-center middle-center middle-right middle-right" "bottom-left bottom-left bottom-center bottom-center bottom-right bottom-right" "bottom-left bottom-left bottom-center bottom-center bottom-right bottom-right"; }
```

## Justification

I ran across #2379, and I appreciate @nex3's answer in that current SASS does not support multi-line indented properties. However, I accidentally discovered that SASS does support the following:

from:
```sass
foo:
  bar: "foo"
  baz: "bar"
```

to:
```css
foo-bar: "foo";
foo-baz: "bar";
```

And it got me thinking that what if SASS could support a similar syntax that would be parsed into indented multi-line properties? A dash to denote an "array"-like structure that simply becomes a concatenated value separated by spaces, as in my example above with `grid-template-areas`. One drawback, which may or may not be an issue, is that there is not a good way to denote what the delimiter should be (are there CSS properties that use other delimiters?)

Another idea that could take into account arbitrary delimiters (now or into the future) may be to use a more array-like structure by including square brackets:

from:
```sass
main
  grid-template-areas: [
      "top"
      "middle"
      "bottom"
  ]
```

to:
```css
body main {
    grid-template-areas: "top" "middle" "bottom"; }
```

And whatever delimiter is used between items would be the delimiter. Essentially, this example would do nothing more than collapse the newlines into one line:

from:
```sass
main
  grid-template-areas: [
      "top",
      "middle",
      "bottom"
  ]
```

to:
```css
main {
      grid-template-areas: "top", "middle", "bottom"; }
```
(assuming this is valid CSS, of course)

All but the very first example (the one under Expected Results) are all contrived, of course. I am working on a project that may have a very intricate and complex grid, and it would be a nightmare to have to maintain it as one line. 

My hope here is to get (and keep) a discussion going with the developers and the community about addressing this elephant in the room so that we can all move on to bigger and better things. :)

Thank you!

version info:
```cmd
$ node-sass --version
node-sass       4.12.0  (Wrapper)       [JavaScript]
libsass         3.5.4   (Sass Compiler) [C/C++]
```

items.title: libsass throws on non-selector psuedo selector params
call()'s first argument should be named $function

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: The first argument to the `call()` function should be named `$function`. It used to be named `$name` in Ruby Sass, but this was changed in Dart Sass because it no longer takes a function name, and LibSass should update as well.

items.title: keywords() should preserve underscores in argument names

labels.name: Compatibility - P2
labels.description: Moderately important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: If the `keywords()` function is used on an arglist with arguments that were originally passed with underscores, it should return a map with underscore-separated keys.

items.title: feature-exists()'s parameter name should be $feature

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: LibSass lists `feature-exists()`'s parameter name as `$name`, but it should be `$feature` to match Dart and Ruby Sass.

items.title: str-slice() should require integer indexes

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: `str-slice("", 0.5)` and `str-slice("", 1, 1.5)` should both throw errors because `$start-at` and `$end-at`, respectively, aren't integers. Instead in LibSass they return `""`.

items.title: str-insert() should require an integer index

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: `str-insert("", "", 0.5)` should throw an error because `$index` isn't an integer. Instead in LibSass it returns `""`.

items.title: str-slice() should allow very negative $start-at values

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: `str-slice("cde", -100)` should return `"cde"`, but in LibSass it throws an error with the text `utf8::not_enough_room`.

items.title: comparable() arguments have the wrong names

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: LibSass's `comparable()` function has argument names `$number-1` and `$number-2`. To match Dart Sass and be consistent with other built-in functions, they should be `$number1` and `$number2`.

items.title: min() and max() produce misleading errors when no arguments are passed
items.body: When no arguments are passed to the `min()` and `max()` functions, they produce `Error: Function min` (or `max`) `finished without @return`. They should probably produce a clearer error explaining that one argument is required.

items.title: Consider releasing a patch update for Windows builds
items.body:
5ebc5d5 made it much easier to build libsass on CI. This is quite an improvement for downstream projects.
For example with this commit it is possible to build libsass on Travis (Windows) without any additional setup. Prior it was simply not possbile.

Would you consider making a patch release so that downstream could use this?

items.title: scale-color() produces incorrect colors

labels.name: Compatibility - P2
labels.description: Moderately important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body:
LibSass's `scale-color()` function output doesn't match that of Dart Sass or Ruby Sass in a number of cases:

```
scale-color(turquoise, $saturation: 24%, $lightness: -48%)
  should be #10867a, is actually #0d897c
scale-color(plum, $saturation: 67%)
  should be #f489f4, is actually #e895e8
scale-color(plum, $saturation: 100%)
  should be #ff7eff, is actually #ed90ed
```

There are likely other cases that are invalid as well.

items.title: invert() shouldn't allow both a number and a weight

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: The `invert()` function allows a number to be passed in order to support the plain-CSS `invert()` filter. However, if this is done, it should forbid the weight parameter from being passed as well.

items.title: mix() color arguments have the wrong names

labels.name: Compatibility - P3
labels.description: Minorly important for compatibility with the Sass spec and ecosystem

items.body: Way back in 2013, in https://github.com/sass/ruby-sass/commit/603cbf4011f3df6aaa2a860fa32589a9dc48a3c5, Ruby Sass updated the argument names for `mix()` to be `$color1` and `$color2` rather than `$color-1` and `$color-2`, for consistency with other core library functions. It looks like LibSass never did the corresponding update, though, and still has the old argument names.

items.title: .editorconfig pattern for GNUmakefile.am incorrect
items.body:
The `.editorconfig` file currently contains the pattern:

```ini
[{Makefile, GNUmakefile.am}]
```

The space at the start of ` GNUmakefile.am` is matched literally and so doesn't actually match the `GNUmakefile.am` file in the repo.

items.title: Does LibSASS have a precompiled partials cache?
items.body:
This is not a bug, but rather a potential feature request. I haven’t found any information highlighting how LibSass caching works, so opening this ticket to clarify things.

I’ve also posted same ticket at [DartSASS](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/issues/649).

In Browserify we have caching mechanism, which stores pre-compiled partials. This notably shortens repeated processing times by eliminating FS/IO, parsing, transformation and sourcemaps generation.

In SASS, however, it’s more complex, since precompiled partials should also contain transpile-time context such as variables, mixins and functions.

Do you think it’s possible to cache precompiled partials? If no, can we at least cache pre-parsed partials?

I’ve done NodeSASS vs DartSASS performance comparison. Here is what I’ve found:

- NodeSASS and DartSASS performance behavior is identical;
- NodeSASS is 10-12% faster than DartSASS;
- Enabling Fibers for DartSASS doesn’t make any difference (OS X 10.14.4, Node 11.10.1);

I’ve seen [this](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/pull/326) feature merged into DartSASS, stating it’ll allow to cache imports across compilations. Wondering if it's deployed and can be used.

In general, LibSASS and DartSASS are both fast, but still there is a room for improvement. What do you think?

items.title: Treat FF, CR, and CR LF as LF
items.body:
[The CSS spec](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-syntax-3/#input-preprocessing) says that "U+000D CARRIAGE RETURN (CR) code points, U+000C FORM FEED (FF) code points, or pairs of U+000D CARRIAGE RETURN (CR) followed by U+000A LINE FEED (LF)" should be treated as U+000A LINE FEED characters, but LibSass seems to treat them like any other character in some circumstances.

In particular, all of these characters (or character sequences) are passed through as-is if they appear in comments. If they're used to terminate a line in the indented syntax, CR and CR LF work as expected but FF fails.

items.title: Edge case: division followed by a slash operation should be treated as division
items.body: The expression `1 / 2 / x` should be compiled to `0.5/x`, because `/` should be treated as division if it's used as part of another arithmetic expression. LibSass currently compiles it to `1 / 2 / x`.

items.title: SyntaxError using CSS fraction (fr) unit
Final digit of some decimal numbers is dropped
items.body:
LibSass compiles the number in `a {b: (133.3333633333%)}` to `133.333363333%`—note that the output has only four `3`s after the `6`, rather than the five in the original number.

This reproduces with any precision value 10 or above (also with precision 9, but you'd expect that to truncate the number).

items.title: inspect() should return an unquoted string when passed a quoted string
items.body:
Currently, when LibSass's `inspect()` function is passed a quoted string, it returns that string as-is. It should instead return an unquoted string that contains the text of the quoted string as it would be written in a Sass file. For example, `inspect("a")` should return `unquote('"a"')`, but it currently returns `"a"`.

Originally reported in https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/issues/594.

items.title: Feature request: Using the :host() function pseudo-class with parent selectors
3.5.[45] does not pass latest-tagged sass-spec
items.body:
When using a tagged version of everything, tests do not all pass. Since there is no sass-spec 3.5.5 to use, I will use 3.5.4 as example:
```bash
# Clone all:
$ git clone https://github.com/sass/libsass.git
$ cd libsass
$ ./script/bootstrap

# Switch to tagged versions:
$ git checkout 3.5.4
$ git -C sassc checkout 3.5.0
$ git -C sass-spec checkout v3.5.4

# Build
$ autoreconf -vfi
$ ./configure --enable-tests
$ make -j$NPROC

# Run tests
$ ./script/spec
```
which fails 2 tests:
```
  1) Failure:
SassSpec::Test#test__sass-spec/spec/sass/import/unquoted [.../libsass/sass-spec/lib/sass_spec/test.rb:180]:
Command `libsass` did not complete:

Error: File to import not found or unreadable: unquoted, sub/unquoted.
        on line 1 of /sass/spec/sass/import/unquoted/input.sass
>> @import "unquoted, sub/unquoted";

   ^
.
Expected: 0
  Actual: 65

  2) Failure:
SassSpec::Test#test__sass-spec/spec/libsass-closed-issues/issue_2360 [.../libsass/sass-spec/lib/sass_spec/test.rb:269]:
expected did not match output.
--- expected
+++ actual
@@ -1,4 +1,3 @@
 # encoding: ASCII-8BIT
-"@value test_1 #555;
-@value test_2 rgb(0,255,0);
+"@value test_1 #555 {}@value test_2 rgb(0,255,0) {}
 "
```
If you use libsass 3.5.5 and sass-spec 3.5.4 (there is no newer tag), then there are 20 failures. I won't copy out all of them here, but they are mostly deprecation warnings. I assume a new tag of sass-spec will fix those.

However, the above two failures still do not go away with 3.5.5. Are 3.5.[45] (slightly?) broken or sass-spec?

items.title: test directory appears unused
items.body:
The `test` directory contains files that are never compiled, nor are the referenced in any Makefile. They seem to be broken as well, using include paths that are no longer correct. The `test` directory also shadows the `test` Makefile target, causing `make test` to sometimes report 'nothing to do' instead of running tests.

Can these files be removed now?

items.title: feature request: : Add a flag to turn off DEPRECATION WARNS
items.body:
Since version 4.9 of [node-sass](https://github.com/sass/node-sass) the current warning is being shown in a lot of projects. ([you may see an open issue asking for a way to silence the warning here](https://github.com/sass/node-sass/issues/2334))
```
DEPRECATION WARNING: Passing a string to call() is deprecated and will be illegal
in Sass 4.0. Use call(get-function("variable-exists")) instead.
```
The warning is ok and i would love to fix all my deprecated functions call but i can't, the main reason is that i don't even know which library is the one with the issue... (is not my code) i understand the need to force everyone to update their deprecated stuff, but that's not feasible. I think every developer is responsible for their own application and taking the risk to be outdated is on their own, i accept the responsibility :)

**And so... this feature request is to add somewhere somehow a flag that can be turned on/off the `DEPRECATION WARNINGS`** 

I've already mistakenly tried to add an environment variable at the node-sass project, but @nschonni told me that the PR should be done here at `libsass`, however @xzyfer told me that the acceptable solution to silencing deprecation warnings is to fix the deprecated code, even thought that the code belongs to someone else, a library.

- You may se the code to add the flag is already available at [PR-2587](https://github.com/sass/node-sass/pull/2587) from [node-sass](https://github.com/sass/node-sass) project, is not much.
- Also the open issue regarding this matter is [2334](https://github.com/sass/node-sass/issues/2334) (also from node-sass project).

items.title: --linefeed settings is ignored by --source-map-contents true
items.body:
Hello,

if I build css file with "node-sass --source-map-embed --source-map-contents --linefeed lf to/path/file.scss" via npm script, then the containing "sourcesContent" linefeed is on Linux \n and on Windows \r\n.

e.g. decoded base64 source maps on Linux:
```
{
	"version": 3,
	"file": "src/main/resources/test/resource/index.css",
	"sources": [
		...
	],
	"sourcesContent": [
		"@import \"abstracts/mixins\";\n@import \"base/editor\";\n
		...
	],
	"names": [],
	"mappings": ...
}
```
and Windows:
```
{
	"version": 3,
	"file": "src/main/resources/test/resource/index.css",
	"sources": [
		...
	],
	"sourcesContent": [
		"@import \"abstracts/mixins\";\r\n@import \"base/editor\";\r\n
		...
	],
	"names": [],
	"mappings": ...
}
```
The setting: "--source-map-contents" should use the settings of --linefeed.

- NPM version: 3.10.10 and 6.4.1
- Node version: v6.10.0 and v10.15.0
- Node Process: { http_parser: '2.7.0',
  node: '6.10.0',
  v8: '5.1.281.93',
  uv: '1.9.1',
  zlib: '1.2.8',
  ares: '1.10.1-DEV',
  icu: '58.2',
  modules: '48',
  openssl: '1.0.2k' }
- Node Platform: win32
- Node architecture: ia32
- node-sass version:
      node-sass       4.11.0  (Wrapper)       [JavaScript]
      libsass         3.5.4   (Sass Compiler) [C/C++]

- npm node-sass versions: `-- node-sass@4.11.0

PS: Thanks for the cool lib/language

Related: https://github.com/sass/node-sass/issues/2585

items.title: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow
items.body:

Compile and reproduce:
`CC=afl-clang-fast CXX=afl-clang-fast++ AFL_USE_ASAN=1 make -C sassc -j4`
